body: Awesome. :+1:

Perhaps someone with some more Antlr 2 secret powers than me can help remove the warning:

```
[ant:antlr] groovy.g: warning:lexical nondeterminism between rules ML_COMMENT and REGEXP_LITERAL upon
[ant:antlr] groovy.g:     k==1:'/'
[ant:antlr] groovy.g:     k==2:'*'
[ant:antlr] groovy.g:     k==3:'\^@'..'\ufffe'
[ant:antlr] groovy.g:     k==4:'\^@'..'\ufffe'
```
Merged. Thanks!
Maybe @jespersm has a idea how to remove the warning?
They can be removed.
it's been squashed into a single commit, please review it
BTW: I tried, but I don't get why the warning occurs, the lookahead seems correctly specified.

OK, thanks for checking. I ended up using a disambiguating semantic predicate and had to have it in it's own method so that the `atMultiCommentStart()` and `!atMultiCommentStart()` alternatives were recognized as distinct alternatives. Seems happy now but there might be a simpler way I couldn't fathom.
Thanks! Nice works as usual! :+1:

Thanks for the pull request. :+1: 

Sadly the merge of this pull causes several test to fail:

http://ci.groovy-lang.org/viewLog.html?buildId=24237&tab=buildResultsDiv&buildTypeId=Groovy_Jdk6Build&guest=1

It would be very nice if you could take a look.
Thanks! :)

Now Teamcity looks good :)

Nice :)

Thanks for all your effort. :+1: 

It looks like the changes to the test are not necessary. I was able to run the test locally on windows without the changes and a pull request without the test changes runs on the buildserver: http://ci.groovy-lang.org/viewLog.html?buildId=24483&tab=buildResultsDiv&buildTypeId=Groovy_Jdk7Build

It would be nice if you could revert the changes to the tests and squash all commits.

I will then try to motivate a member of the groovy team more knowledgeable about this code to do a review. Hopefully we can merge this pull request soon.

Thanks,
Pascal

Hello Pascal,

after fighting some time with github (I'm more or less new to it ...) I squashed my commits to one.

Greetings,
Marcus

Hi Marcus,

great :).

I used to struggle a lot with git/github (still do sometimes), it's a 
lot to learn.

I just sent this mail to the developer mailing list:

-------- Weitergeleitete Nachricht --------
Betreff:    GROOVY-7018 GroovyClassLoader addClasspath RegexPattern issue 
/ Review of pull request 43
Datum:  Tue, 30 Jun 2015 22:44:53 +0200
Von:    Pascal Schumacher
Antwort an:     dev@groovy.incubator.apache.org
An:     dev@groovy.incubator.apache.org

Hi everybody,

multiple people reported to be affected by this regression
(https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GROOVY-7018) and Jochen scheduled
it to be fixed in multiple 2.3.X versions, but we never got around to
actually fix it.

Now we got a pull request
(https://github.com/apache/incubator-groovy/pull/43) which passes all
tests on the ci server
(http://ci.groovy-lang.org/viewLog.html?buildId=24487&tab=buildResultsDiv&buildTypeId=Groovy_Jdk7Build)
and looks o.k. to me.

It would be very nice, if anybody more knowledgeable in this area could
do review.

Thanks and kind regards,
Pascal
I actually wonder about if we try to avoid using the pattern by building on top of the exception mechanism in GroovyClassLoader, then why don't we do the same logic in GroovyMain?

Hello blackdrag,

that's what i thought about as well.

In fact one reason for me is, that in GroovyMain the given "script" String has to be an existing file if it is a scriptfile. In the ClassLoader it is possible to write pathes in the classpath which doesn't actually exist, but could exist later. That's why we can use file.exists() in GroovyMain, while this check isn't working for any cases in the ClassLoader.

Another reason is, that the defined URI pattern is completely RFC conform and it just fails in Cygwin environments if the given script is created with a false cygpath call. This problem is catched by using the file instead of the URI. But if we got a correct URI in GroovyMain (the only way to determine if it's correct, if we ignore this exception driven development I had to implement in the ClassLoader, is to use the pattern) we should use this URI as is.

I'm not sure which way is the better one. My solution in the GroovyClassloader should also work in GroovyMain, but if we would use it, we couldn't remove the URI pattern because it is already used in `public String getText(String uriOrFilename)` as well.

Greets,
Marcus

Jochen, I think our fixes are logically equivalent for the cases we have been given. For trickier cases, I don't think they are quite the same but I'm not fully confident which would be the best way to go - so happy to go with yours and if something trickier ever arises we can reassess options at that point. Such trickier cases would certainly be questionable style in any case.

Looks good - any chance you can add a test case which currently fails and is fixed after the change? If we don't hear from you we'll create one ourselves but if you can add it, that will speed up inclusion of your change. Thanks.

I kinda figured that was the case.  It's cool.. We good with putting in 2.4.5?  Or should it go in 2.5.0?  I was thinking the former since it won't break anything.

while you did add method for the wrapper types, I do miss the null-check, like it is for example in the null taking method. Plus... well this is an extra, but I would suggest reusing the primitive typed methods from the wrapper typed methods to not have the logic (even though it is small) twice.
Thanks Keegan. Can you put a more descriptive commit message? ticket number + description is enough.
No problem.  Message amended.
Thanks!

The null check didn't seem to be needed for the test included in the PR? In fact, everything is routed via the Object variant - hence why the null checks aren't needed for the wrapper variants. But when the wrapper variants aren't added the static compilation is matching the primitive methods and triggering the need for boxing.

If the Object taking method is used, it means type information is lost somewhere or not used for this combination with CompileStatic. That's bound to be another bug somewhere, which would surface NPEs once fixed.
This was actually merged with c3a802fe13a6fc7267130db805940bd2be41b4f8.  I messed up the commit message.
I mixed up the PR number of my #68 merge with this PR, I've opened #78 to re-request the merge.

For improving import aliasing you can take the material from http://www.groovy-lang.org/style-guide.html.
hoping to get time to look soon

Seems like I overlooked the implementation of "<<<" and ">>>" when I did primitive optimizations, which is why CompileStatic  inherits the problem. The fix you did will prevent the message, but it won't be fast. Fast it can be only if boxing is avoided. But your example is special, because it involves the power operator, for which we have no direct bytecode instruction and have to use the slower paths. So I am partial about applying this fix as is
@blackdrag: Thanks for the response. Can you say me or point to already in the source how to do slower paths? So that I can update my PR.
merged

That is very common slang for Windows to hint that some people think it slow and sleepy but you are correct that we might as well fix it up. However, we wouldn't fix `gradlew.bat` since that is a generated file from gradle and the change will only be erased next time we upgrade gradle. You could raise a similar report to the gradle folk if you felt so inclined and if changed would eventually find it's way back into a future version of Groovy. Could you remove that file from your PR? Thanks.
While you're at it, could you add a comma before the "and Geb for..."?
Do you mind if I change your commit message to "fixed typos in TypeCheckingContext Javadoc"?
Please edit the PR description and commit message to something more descriptive.  Maybe something like "rename 'Different keywords' section to 'Extra keywords'".
Not at all.
Thanks!
I detected a small bug for completion inside an argument, maybe wait before merging...
Sure, I'll do it with pleasure. Do you think it would be convenient to drop this pull request and submit a new one with this changes plus the comma?

Thank you.  I could have changed myself, but I dislike 1 character commits.

You can open a new PR if you want, but I like to have the conversation in one place on GitHub.  Since it's not like PRs make a snapshot of the content when they're opened, what I usually do in these cases is
1. Commit the change
2. Squash it with your previous commit locally
3. Force push with `git push origin +master`

Overwriting the history like that is evil to do on a repo someone might fork.  But for cases like this, nobody's gonna fork a fork, so it's fine.
It's done. Cheers.
I think the bug is in jline 2.13 and so this only concerns #93, so this PR here can be reviewed and merged

There may be several regressions in JLine 2.13, I found this one:
https://github.com/jline/jline2/issues/208

I think it might be wise to wait for a bit, since 2.13 seems to have done some risky changes (JLine does not have that many unit tests).
Thanks!
My pleasure.

The PR looks good to me!
Thanks!

rebased and added another little fix to escaping (with test)

Also added another fix with test, where it is impossible to use a defined class in interpreter mode:

```
groovy:000> class Me { String name }
===> true
groovy:000> m = new Me()
script14405523893121089774169.groovy: 2: unable to resolve class Me 
```

The fix is to use the shell's classloader as parent classloader to the Scriptanalyzer, so that the classes can be loaded. This was broken also in all of 2.4
@paulk-asert Sure, I've reverted the changes to `gradlew.bat`, and force pushed a rebased commit.
seems this breaks test, will repoen after fixing...
